sub_topic: Finding the antiderivative of a function
message_1: Find the antiderivative of the function f(x) = 3x^2 - 4x + 5.
message_2:
To find the antiderivative of the function f(x) = 3x^2 - 4x + 5, we will integrate the function with respect to x. 

The antiderivative F(x) is given by:

F(x) = ∫(3x^2 - 4x + 5) dx

We will integrate each term separately:

∫(3x^2) dx = (3/3) x^3 + C1 = x^3 + C1

∫(-4x) dx = (-4/2) x^2 + C2 = -2x^2 + C2

∫(5) dx = 5x + C3

Now, we will add the results of the three integrals:

F(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 + 5x + (C1 + C2 + C3)

Since C1, C2, and C3 are constants of integration, we can combine them into a single constant, C:

F(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 + 5x + C

So, the antiderivative of the function f(x) = 3x^2 - 4x + 5 is F(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 + 5x + C.
